name: Cujada (Potato and Egg Pie)
name_origin: The name derives directly from the Ladino (Judeo-Spanish) word 'Quajado' or Spanish 'Cuajada'. It comes from the verb 'cuajar' (to coagulate, curdle, or set). While in modern Spain 'cuajada' refers to a dairy curd dessert, in Sephardic culinary terminology, it refers to a savory casserole where eggs are used as the binding agent to 'set' the vegetables (potatoes, spinach, or leeks). The presence of this name in a Djerban cookbook likely reflects the influence of the 'Grana' (Livornese/European Jewish community in Tunisia) or general Sephardic diaspora terminology, as the indigenous Tunisian Arabic term for this exact dish is 'Maaqouda'.
description: A savory North African potato and egg pie, similar to a Tunisian Maaqouda or a crustless quiche. The potatoes are mashed and seasoned with turmeric and garlic before being baked into a golden, fluffy casserole.
cultural_context: A staple in Djerban and North African Jewish households, often served at room temperature for Shabbat lunch or as a side dish for holidays.
vegan_adaptation_notes: Requires eggs for binding; difficult to adapt while maintaining traditional texture.

ingredients.name: Chicken bouillon powder
ingredients.notes: Listed as 'Chicken broth' in original; powder is typical for binding

steps.instruction: Boil the potatoes in water until they are completely soft.
steps.tips: They should be soft enough to mash easily.

steps.instruction: Drain the potatoes and mash them well in a large bowl.
Season the mashed potatoes with turmeric (or saffron), white pepper, chicken bouillon powder, salt, garlic powder, and the baking powder. Mix well.
Add the eggs to the potato mixture and mix until fully combined into a uniform batter.
steps.tips: Ensure the potatoes have cooled slightly so the eggs don't scramble upon contact.

steps.instruction: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Pour the oil into an oven-safe pot or deep baking dish and heat it (on the stove or in the oven) until hot.
steps.tips: Heating the oil first creates a crust and prevents sticking.

steps.instruction: Carefully pour the potato-egg mixture into the hot oil.
Bake in the oven until the pie is set, golden on top, and a toothpick inserted into the center comes out dry.

variants.name: Hard-boiled Egg Variation
variants.description: Some family versions (Maaqouda) include whole or chopped hard-boiled eggs inside the batter before baking.

name_etymology.meaning: That which is set/curdled/coagulated (referring to the eggs binding the dish)
name_etymology.notes: Linguistically confirmed via Spanish/Ladino roots. The shift from dairy-setting to egg-setting is a standard semantic shift in Sephardic cooking (e.g., 'Quajado de Prasa'). The Hebrew spelling קוז'אדה uses the 'zh' sound (zayin with geresh) to approximate the Ladino 'J' sound.

alternative_names.name: Quajado
alternative_names.notes: Standard spelling in Turkish/Rhodesli Sephardic communities.

alternative_names.name: Maaqouda
alternative_names.notes: The most common name for this potato-egg pie in Tunisia (literally 'the knotted/bound one').

alternative_names.name: Mina
alternative_names.notes: A similar Sephardic pie, though usually made with matzah layers (Mina de patata).

similar_dishes.name: Maaqouda / Maâkouda
similar_dishes.similarity: Identical ingredients (mashed potato, egg, parsley, turmeric).
similar_dishes.key_difference: In Morocco, Maaqouda are often small fried patties; in Tunisia, it is often a baked pie (Tagine Maaqouda) identical to Cujada.

similar_dishes.name: Tortilla de Patatas
similar_dishes.key_difference: Cooked in a skillet (flipped) rather than baked in an oven; uses sliced potatoes rather than mashed.

similar_dishes.name: Potato Kugel
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses grated raw potatoes (denser texture) rather than cooked mashed potatoes; lacks the turmeric/cumin profile.

similar_dishes.name: Sfereeya
similar_dishes.key_difference: Sfereeya specifically incorporates chicken, whereas Cujada/Maaqouda is often vegetarian.

intro_paragraph: Cujada takes its name from the Spanish *cuajar* ("to set"), referring to the eggs that bind this savory potato pie. Similar to a crustless quiche or *maaqouda*, the mashed potato mixture is spiced with turmeric and garlic, then baked until golden. A fixture of Djerban Jewish tables, it is traditionally served at room temperature for Shabbat lunch.
